Key Arguments: The bill could unduly impact the legitimate exercise of free speech and freedom of religion.
The broad nature of the bill could lead to censorship of unpopular views under the guise of combating misinformation.
The bill grants excessive power to ACMA without sufficient checks and balances.
The definition of misinformation and disinformation is problematic and subjective.
Exemptions for educational institutions are insufficient and could be eroded over time.
The bill could negatively impact the free expression of religion and other forms of expression like political and artistic speech.
Notable Quotes: CET has serious concerns that the Bill will unduly impact on the legitimate exercise of free speech.
The incentive structure of the proposed Bill will be for digital operators to suppress information, if in doubt.
The bill, as currently drafted, has the potential to impact on these fundamental rights.
The Bill grants ACMA too broad a power to make that value judgement as to what might cause harm.
